<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 276, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
0625/63  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 326, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 6 Alternative to Practical  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 300, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2024  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[853, 325, 905, 340]]<|/det|>
1 hour  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 433]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 559]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 213, 602]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 910, 91]]<|/det|>
A student investigates how the volume of water affects the rate at which water in a beaker cools.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 468, 121]]<|/det|>
She uses the apparatus shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 129, 811, 425]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 435, 532, 454]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 466, 146, 485]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 465, 747, 485]]<|/det|>
Record the room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) shown on the thermometer in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 495, 920, 515]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta_{\mathrm{R}} =\) ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 496, 920, 515]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 527, 146, 546]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 527, 920, 561]]<|/det|>
The student pours a volume of \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker and records the temperature \(\theta\) of the water at time \(t = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 573, 702, 592]]<|/det|>
She records the temperature of the water in the beaker every 30 s.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 604, 839, 623]]<|/det|>
She pours the water out and pours a volume of \(75 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 635, 789, 654]]<|/det|>
The student repeats the temperature measurements for this volume of water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 183, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 71, 920, 104]]<|/det|> Describe two precautions that can be taken to ensure that temperature readings in the experiment are as accurate as possible. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 116, 212, 134]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 148, 917, 166]]<|/det|>
2
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 180, 917, 203]]<|/det|>
2

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 650, 920, 668]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 681, 146, 700]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 681, 895, 700]]<|/det|> Write a conclusion stating how the volume of water affects the rate of cooling of the water. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 712, 542, 730]]<|/det|> Justify your answer by reference to the results. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 835, 920, 853]]<|/det|> [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 180, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Using the values for \(75 \text{cm}^3\) of water, calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{1}\) for the first \(90 \text{s}\) of the experiment. Use the readings from Table 2.1 and the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[443, 112, 556, 141]]<|/det|>
\[x_{1} = \frac{\theta_{0} - \theta_{90}}{T}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 148, 792, 167]]<|/det|>
where \(T = 90 \text{s}\) and \(\theta_{0}\) and \(\theta_{90}\) are the temperatures at \(t = 0\) and \(t = 90 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 164, 487, 183]]<|/det|>
Include the unit for the cooling rate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 225, 920, 243]]<|/det|>
<form>\(x_{1} =\) ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 256, 920, 291]]<|/det|>
Using the values for \(75 \text{cm}^3\) of water, calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{2}\) for the last \(90 \text{s}\) of the experiment. Use the readings from Table 2.1 and the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 295, 564, 327]]<|/det|>
\[x_{2} = \frac{\theta_{90} - \theta_{180}}{T}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 335, 839, 354]]<|/det|>
where \(T = 90 \text{s}\) and \(\theta_{90}\) and \(\theta_{180}\) are the temperatures at \(t = 90 \text{s}\) and \(t = 180 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 396, 920, 415]]<|/det|>
<form>\(x_{2} =\) ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 413, 920, 432]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 443, 180, 462]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 443, 920, 477]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 603, 89]]<|/det|>
A student determines the focal length of a converging lens.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 101, 222, 118]]<|/det|>
illuminated object

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 114, 928, 203]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 218, 532, 237]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 250, 146, 269]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 250, 616, 269]]<|/det|>
The student sets up the apparatus as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 281, 798, 299]]<|/det|>
He sets the distance \(u\) between the illuminated object and the lens to \(25.0 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 312, 920, 345]]<|/det|>
He places the screen near the lens and moves the screen until a focused image of the illuminated object is seen on the screen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 358, 756, 377]]<|/det|>
Describe a technique for obtaining an image that is as sharp as possible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 483, 148, 502]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 483, 920, 516]]<|/det|>
The shapes of the illuminated object and the image seen on the screen are shown full size in Fig. 3.2 and Fig. 3.3.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[203, 526, 416, 682]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[567, 524, 826, 680]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[275, 696, 346, 715]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[662, 696, 734, 715]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 728, 183, 746]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 727, 767, 746]]<|/det|>
Measure \(h_{\mathrm{O}}\), the height of the illuminated object, as shown in Fig. 3.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 757, 920, 776]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 789, 787, 808]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 819, 920, 838]]<|/det|>

<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 863, 885, 888]]<|/det|>

G = ....................................................... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 841, 920, 860]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 868, 181, 887]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 868, 747, 887]]<|/det|> The focal length \(f\) of the lens is numerically equal to the gradient \(G\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 897, 517, 915]]<|/det|> Record a value of \(f\) for this experiment. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[556, 927, 920, 945]]<|/det|> f = .................................................... cm <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[871, 935, 920, 952]]<|/det|> [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 730, 88]]<|/det|>
A student decides to continue the experiment using larger values of \(u\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 601, 120]]<|/det|>
Explain why this produces less accurate values for \(W\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 210, 923, 228]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 227, 923, 246]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the relationship between the diameter of a wire and the electrical resistance of the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment which enables her to investigate how the diameter of a wire affects the resistance of the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 161, 544, 183]]<|/det|>
Resistance \(R\) is calculated from the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 195, 833, 212]]<|/det|>
where \(V\) is the potential difference (p.d.) across the wire and \(I\) is the current in the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 226, 683, 244]]<|/det|>
The apparatus available includes wires of different known diameters.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 259, 225, 275]]<|/det|>
In your plan:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 289, 457, 306]]<|/det|>
· list any additional apparatus needed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 304, 823, 320]]<|/det|>
· complete Fig. 4.1 to show a circuit suitable for measuring the resistance of a wire

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 319, 920, 351]]<|/det|>
· explain briefly how to do the experiment, including the measurements to take so that the resistance can be determined

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 351, 494, 368]]<|/det|>
· state the key variables to keep constant

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 367, 920, 399]]<|/det|>
· draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display the readings (you are not required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 396, 606, 413]]<|/det|>
· explain how to use the readings to reach a conclusion.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[275, 422, 715, 616]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 634, 532, 651]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label>
